problem_text: If a cartoon character is funny, then it is popular. If a cartoon character is ugly, then it is not popular. If a cartoon character is loved by children, then it is funny. If a cartoon character is from The Simpsons, then it is loved by children. If a cartoon character is yellow, then it is from The Simpsons. Ben is either from The Simpsons or funny.
predicates:
Funny(x) ::: x is a funny cartoon character.
Popular(x) ::: x is a popular cartoon character.
Ugly(x) ::: x is an ugly cartoon character.
LovedByChildren(x) ::: x is loved by children.
FromSimpsons(x) ::: x is from The Simpsons.
Ben(x) ::: x is Ben.

tests.questions: Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? Ben is either a cartoon character that is loved by children or a funny cartoon character.
tests.conclusions: LovedByChildren(ben) ⊕ Funny(ben) ::: Ben is either a cartoon character that is loved by children or a funny cartoon character. TRUE

tests.questions: Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is a cartoon character that is loved by children, then Ben is a funny cartoon character.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is from The Simpsons, then Ben is not ugly.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? Ben is a cartoon character that is not popular.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is funny, then Ben is loved by children.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is a funny cartoon character and a cartoon character from The Simpsons, then Ben is ugly.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is a cartoon character that is not popular, then Ben is not funny.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is a funny cartoon character and is loved by children, then Ben is not ugly.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is funny, then Ben is popular.
Based on the above information, is the following statement true or false? If Ben is a cartoon character that is loved by children, then Ben is popular.

candidate_solutions.text:
# Predicates:
Funny(x) ::: x is a funny cartoon character.
Popular(x) ::: x is a popular cartoon character.
Ugly(x) ::: x is an ugly cartoon character.
LovedByChildren(x) ::: x is loved by children.
FromSimpsons(x) ::: x is from The Simpsons.
Ben(x) ::: x is Ben.

# Premises:
∀x (Funny(x) → Popular(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is funny, then it is popular.
∀x (Ugly(x) → ¬Popular(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is ugly, then it is not popular.
∀x (LovedByChildren(x) → Funny(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is loved by children, then it is funny.
∀x (FromSimpsons(x) → LovedByChildren(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is from The Simpsons, then it is loved by children.
∀x (Yellow(x) → FromSimpsons(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is yellow, then it is from The Simpsons.
FromSimpsons(ben) ∨ Funny(ben) ::: Ben is either from The Simpsons or funny.

# Predicates:
Funny(x) ::: x is a funny cartoon character.
Popular(x) ::: x is a popular cartoon character.
Ugly(x) ::: x is an ugly cartoon character.
LovedByChildren(x) ::: x is loved by children.
FromSimpsons(x) ::: x is from The Simpsons.
Ben(x) ::: x is Ben.

# Premises:
∀x (Popular(x) → Funny(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is popular, then it is funny.
∀x (¬Popular(x) → ¬Ugly(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is not popular, then it is not ugly.
∀x (Funny(x) → LovedByChildren(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is funny, then it is loved by children.
∀x (LovedByChildren(x) → FromSimpsons(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is loved by children, then it is from The Simpsons.
∀x (FromSimpsons(x) → Yellow(x)) ::: If a cartoon character is from The Simpsons, then it is yellow.
Funny(ben) ∨ FromSimpsons(ben) ::: Ben is either funny or from The Simpsons.

# Predicates:
Funny(x) ::: x is a funny cartoon character.
Popular(x) ::: x is a popular cartoon character.
Ugly(x) ::: x is an ugly cartoon character.
LovedByChildren(x) ::: x is loved by children.
FromSimpsons(x) ::: x is from The Simpsons.
Ben(x) ::: x is Ben.

# Premises:
∀x ((Funny(x) → Popular(x)) ∧ (Ugly(x) → ¬Popular(x)) ∧ (LovedByChildren(x) → Funny(x)) ∧ (FromSimpsons(x) → LovedByChildren(x)) ∧ (Yellow(x) → FromSimpsons(x))) ::: All implications about cartoon characters hold.
(FromSimpsons(ben) ∨ Funny(ben)) ::: Ben is either from The Simpsons or funny.

validation.questions: Based on the above information, is the following statement true, false, or uncertain? Ben is loved by children.
validation.conclusions: LovedByChildren(ben) ::: Ben is loved by children. unknown
